page.title: 14THE OVER HALL OF SAMLESBURY
page.content: SAMLESBURY HALL was built about 1325 by Gilbert de Southworth , whose wife was descended from the first recorded lord of Samlesbury.It is a beautiful timber framed structure, decorated with quatre foils.The Great Hall has an orielwindow and massive timbers support the roof. A window and carved screen which was in the chapel came from Whalley Abbey. The Southworths lived there until 1678 when the Braddylls bought it and removed the beautiful carved woodwork oak panelling and chapel screen to their new home,Conishead Priory. Labourers and handloom weavers rented rooms and it eventually became ruinous. The hall was converted into a pub in 1826, a school in 1850 and a residence for the Harrisons in 1862. In 1925 it was saved from demolition by public sub scription and is now owned by a Trust. There are two priestholes and a ghost.
